chapter.htmlHeader: What are the causes and risk factors?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Most spontaneous miscarriages are caused by abnormalities in the embryo. 
    • Chromosomal abnormalities are the most common cause of first trimester miscarriage (detected in 50–85% of pregnancy tissue specimens after spontaneous miscarriage) [Jurkovic, 2013; ACOG, 2018].
    • Other causes include genetic abnormalities and defects in the development of the placenta or embryo [ACOG, 2018; BMJ, 2017a; ESHRE, 2017]. Up to 95% of abnormal embryos miscarry [Porter et al, 2008].
  • No cause of recurrent miscarriage can be determined in about 50% of couples. Identifiable causes include one or more of the following [Rai and Regan, 2006; Jurkovic, 2013; BMJ, 2017a; ESHRE, 2017]:
    • Thrombophilic abnormalities — these include factor V Leiden (FVL) mutation and prothrombin gene mutation.
    • Immunological abnormalities — antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is found in about 15% of women with recurrent miscarriage [BMJ, 2017a].
    • Anatomical or structural causes — these include uterine abnormalities (such as eptate, bicornuate, or arcuate uterus) and cervical abnormalities (such as cervical incompetence).
    • Genetic abnormalities — these include chromosomal abnormalities in the parents or fetus and other genetic causes.
    • Endocrinological causes — these include polycystic ovarian syndrome, hyperprolactinaemia, thyroid disease, and poorly controlled diabetes mellitus.
    • Infective causes — bacterial vaginosis is a recognised risk factor for late miscarriage [BASHH, 2012].
  • Maternal age and number of previous miscarriages are two independent risk factors for a further miscarriage [RCOG, 2011].
    • The risk of miscarriage increases with increasing maternal age due to a decline in both the number and quality of the remaining oocytes [RCOG, 2011]. A large prospective register linkage study reported the age-related risk of miscarriage in recognized pregnancies to be [Nybo Anderson, 2000]:
      • 93% in women aged 45 years and older.
      • 51% in women aged 40–44 years.
      • 25% in women aged 35–39 years.
      • 15% in women aged 30–34 years.
      • 12% in women aged 25–29 years.
      • 11% in women aged 20–24 years.
      • 13% in women aged 12–19 years.
    • The risk of a further miscarriage increases after each successive pregnancy loss, reaching approximately 40% after three consecutive pregnancy losses, and the prognosis worsens with increasing maternal age [RCOG, 2011].
  • Other risk factors for miscarriage (spontaneous and recurrent) may include [Rai and Regan, 2006; Porter et al, 2008; RCOG, 2011; ACOG, 2018; BMJ, 2017a; BMJ, 2017b; ESHRE, 2017]:
    • Occupational and environmental factors (such as heavy metals, pesticide, high dose radiation, and lack of micronutrients). 
    • Advanced paternal age — the frequency of chromosomal anomalies in sperm appears to increase with age [BMJ, 2017a]. The risk of miscarriage is highest among couples where the woman is aged 35 years or older and the man is aged 40 years or older [RCOG, 2011].
    • Lifestyle factors, such as stress, obesity, and smoking.
      • There is no evidence for a causal association between alcohol consumption and miscarriage. However, excessive alcohol consumption is toxic to the embryo and the fetus, and the Department of Health now recommends that women should not consume any alcohol whilst trying to conceive [RCOG, 2011; DH, 2016].
      • There is no evidence that intercourse during pregnancy can cause an early pregnancy loss [ESHRE, 2017].
      • There is no evidence that using illicit drugs (such as cannabis) is a risk factor for pregnancy loss in women with recurrent miscarriage. However, avoiding illicit drugs is generally recommended, especially during pregnancy [ESHRE, 2017].
